ratings.question_text: The readings/cases/textbooks used in this course were __________ .
Out-of-class assignments for this course were ___________ to my learning.
The workload for this course in comparison to other courses was ___________.
The pace of this class was ____________ for optimal learning.
Field trips were well designed and ran smoothly.
I learned a lot from field trips.
How clearly does the instructor provide explanations of conceptual material?
How responsive to student comments was the instructor?
I would give the instructor of this class an overall rating of:
I would give this course an overall rating of:
Apart from how well the course was taught, how valuable is the course to students with interests similar to yours?
Did you participate in a work group as part of this course?

narratives.question_text: Use the space below to comment on questions 1-14, if you wish
comments: Slow pace. Discussion bogged down by students who didn't do the reading. Maybe could be a two hour class instead of three.
Very bad course, very poor organized and every session almost same topics and discussion. Term project was a mess.

On question 4, I think the pace of the course was uneven. Some contents seemed repetitive and in some classes I felt we were going really fast. Maybe think about how to balance the speed of the class a little better.

12. This course represents a strategic path for re-positioning global environmental leaders in the 21st century by applying systems thinking.Very relevant and timely for application to solve the complex problems in the environment space.

narratives.question_text: What were the best aspects of this course?
comments: The best aspects of the course involved working with a diverse team of students on practical client-based projects with real-world implications.
Working with a client on a concrete project.
Nothing

I think the course in general strengthened my understanding of systems thinking and, most especially, it provided me with the connection of systems thinking to the every day organizational work. Paul and Sachi were exceptional people and made it pleasent to go through the difficulties of the course.
The clear tools and explanations of the phases and strategies one can use when speaking to a person or organization's values then crafting a narrative and network around it.

Getting another viewpoint on how a network is built and what a network is. Coming to the understanding that there are many "groups" that are connected through different people and that I have access to a lot of opportunity through these "groups" that I am a part of.
Client work experience
Meeting and working with my groupmates.
Application of systems thinking to environmental problems and building a network to create change.

narratives.question_text: What aspects of this course need the most improvement?
comments: The course structure changed as the semester went on, which was great, but it still seemed at times that the course was lacking structure. The lecture objectives could have been more clearly outlined in the syllabus.
Class time for projects - needs to be divided in teams, I found that class time for everyone on a particular project did not teach me as much.
All aspects.

The course felt very chaotic to me. I know this is part of the experience, but at some point I think the unorganized pace of the course and the lack of clrity on deliverables played against the learning experience.

The client projects and the pacing / repetition. I felt that multiple lectures simply repeated the points from the previous class, without getting much deeper (and many times, deviating into unrelated debates). Our client project was nightmarish. Coordinating with the undergraduate class is not useful. Although they are extremely talented and capable students, any attempt at working across schedules, work experience, potentially-different content or pacing of the course itself, etc, is not conducive to a group project. The roles and involvement of the TFs seemed to change over the course of the semester: much more consistency is needed there, and everyone involved should be taking the course for 3 credits. Our initial student lead had no idea how to manage a team. What really got to me however, was what was either 1) the underlying disorganization that was revealed when a litany of new actors were added into the network mix and proposal at the last second, or 2) disingenuous selective sharing of information over the course of the semester, culminating in what seemed to amount to a pre-determined funding pitch, with student work and presentations that applied lessons from the class being used and leveraged as a form of independent certification -- the network itself and institute that would serve as the hub seemed to have been known from the outset, but, as far as I could tell, was kept from both the students and the client until the end of the academic year. If this is true, then only do I find it to be unethical, but I also feel it detracts from the legitimacy of the class's work because the outcome of our network proposal was not as organic or original as we may have been led to believe.
When I try to implement the concepts taught into my own life and building my own network - aside from the in-class client work - the teach was very unresponsive and seemed uninterested in helping.
More info on developing group norms. Concrete conversation tactics.
Think of possibility of using specific mapping tools to create maps.

narratives.question_text: Was the relationship between the course lectures and discussion/lab section
comments: The class lectures and discussions drew directly from the assigned readings and Professor Lussier engaged all students in course content until all students had a clear understanding of the material.
Very effective

narratives.question_text: Discuss, if you wish, how this course fits into your overall program.  (Please feel free to describe how the course relates to your academic background.)
comments: I think it fits well for students interested in networks of diverse organizations and to get more understanding of opportunities for partnerships and collaborations across organizations.
Helpful to anyone trying to help a client or themselves build a network.
Learning how to work with people and clients from the deepend.

narratives.question_text: Why did you take this course?
comments: I took this course to explore how to build a diverse and scientific communications network for use in my future policy career.

I wanted to strengthen my background on communication sciences. I was not looking for a systems thinking course (which should be stated more explicitly in the course description), but in the end this did not hurt at all.
I like the different point of view I get from this professor. I like talking with people and therefore building networks seems like a good job for me.
I want to learn how to work with people in a manner that fosters genuine partnerships.
To understand new ways of facilitating sustainable change and advancing creative solutions in a changing and challenging time.

narratives.question_text: Did the knowledge/skills that you gained from the course meet your expectations ?
comments: yes

The course did not meet my expectations on haing a stronger theoretical background on communications, but it compensated by opening systems thinking and networks of organizations as a new field to be discovered.
Somewhat, but not really. I was hoping for more guidance on or examples of narrative and network development.
yes
It helped. Our client was difficult but we were able to work together to create a great end product.
Yes

narratives.question_text: If yes, what were the advantages and disadvantages of the group work?
comments: The advantages of group work included working as part of a diverse team to produce a favorable outcome for real-world client. The group work led to diverse discussions and emergent outcomes. The disadvantages included different levels of buy-in from team members and disproportionate commitments from different team members.

disadvantages that the team was large and a lot of time was spent getting to know how to work together and scheduling meetings. Advantages was the diverse range of knowledge and skills that the team possessed and the different ways we learned to communicate with each other.
All students had different backgrounds, therefore it enriched the final outcome of our project. Con: difficult to manage group dynamics.

Group work is essential for this work and it was in general succesful. I would only add more clarity on final deliverables. I understand the logic of focusing on the group process and not so much on final outcomes, but by the end of the course I felt there was insufficient clarity on what was expected from use, which was an unnecessary stress factor that affected the learning experience.
Not very well-organized...
Advantages: I don't have to do all the work Disadvantages: difficult to control the outcome
Couldn't have done it without them, took some time to get used to.
Helpful to create shared learning amongst students.

narratives.question_text: For students who might consider taking this course, what advice would you give them?
comments: I would recommend that students considering this course take Professor Lussier's fall course "Building Scientific Narratives for Climate Engagement" so they may be familiar with the base core concepts practiced in the first half of this course as students work on their client projects.
Very valuable course. I recommend taking first the fall semester course.

Know that this course does not focus on communications theory. If you want a 'fundamentals of communications' class, look for somethin else. This course focuses on networks and coallition building and provides you with an opportunity for a deeper dive into systems thinking. The learning process can feel chaotic and unorganized, you'll have to deal with uncertainty. In the end, this was a very useful course with a very heartful and dedicated instructor.
It is a useful class to learn about systems thinking if you have not already been exposed to it, but be wary of the end-goal of your group client project. Ours almost felt pre-determined.
Take it. It is an important tool to have.
A lot of meta, and a lot of group work. Will take a lot of time to get right.
Be very flexible and open minded to shift from the normal / simple way of thinking.
